faq_questions.q1: Where are these rockets and UAV's fired from?
faq_questions.a1: Before the Hamas attack on October 7, 2023, rockets were mostly fired from the Gaza Strip, but since then, rockets and also UAV's (i.e. loitering munition, more commonly known as exploding drones) have been fired mostly from South Lebanon, but also from Syria, Iraq and Yemen.
faq_questions.q2: Who is firing these rockets and UAV's?
faq_questions.a2: Palestinian terror organizations from Gaza, namely Hamas and Islamic Jihad, as well as Hezbollah terror organization based in South Lebanon.
faq_questions.q3: What are these rockets and UAVs targeting?
faq_questions.a3: Whether fired from Gaza or South Lebanon, these rockets and UAVs are fired indiscriminately at Israeli towns and cities, deliberately targeting innocent civilians, homes and schools.
faq_questions.a4: In addition to protecting its civilians via a combination of bomb shelters and the deployment of the Iron Dome system, Israel typically responds by air striking terror targets, including launch sites, command and control centers, and weapons storage sites.
faq_questions.a5: The Iron Dome Aerial Defense System is an Israeli air defense system designed to intercept and destroy rockets whose trajectory would take them to an Israeli populated area.
faq_questions.a6: Yes. While Iron Dome intercepts most of the rockets fired at Israeli population, rockets still penetrate the defense system and hit residential areas, including homes and schools.
faq_questions.q7: Where does the alert data come from?
faq_questions.a7: We use the IDF's Home Front Command (Pikud HaOref) rocket alert API, which allows us to easily query for real-time rocket alerts. We aggregate the data and slice & dice the information to provide historical data and other insights.
faq_questions.a8: The real-time rocket alerts we show are queried directly from the Home Front Command's API, which is connected to the IDF's Red Color early-warning system. The Red Color system is Israel's official source for rocket alerts which millions of Israelis rely on for their safety. A real-time alert would show up on the website immediately after there's an alert going off in Israel. In some cases, and depending on your connection, it might take a few seconds for an alert going off in Israel to show up.
faq_questions.q9: Does one alert represent a single rocket?
faq_questions.a9: We only have data on the number of alerts, not on the number of rockets being fired. A single rocket could trigger an alert in multiple locations, depending on the proximity of those locations to each other and the geographical size of those communities. An alert in a specified location typically indicates at least one rocket fired towards that location.
faq_questions.q10: How can I get more granular data?
faq_questions.a10: We'd love to help! Feel free to contact us with more information on your specific use case.

graph_alerts_by_day.title: Alerts by day since Oct 7
graph_alerts_by_day.source_note: Source is estimation only. Based on alert location and its distance from the Gaza Strip vs Southern Lebanon. May or may not include rockets fired by Islamic Jihad (Gaza) or by other Iranian proxies (Southern Lebanon).

time_to_shelter.title_far: You have {{countdownSec}} seconds to get to shelter!
time_to_shelter.text_far: If this was happening in your area, this means a rocket or UAV targeting you was fired roughly {{distanceKM}} km ({{distanceMiles}} miles) away

time_to_shelter.share_title_near: I'd have to get to shelter immediately!
